lesson.name: Lesson 7.10: Graphs of Functions in Standard and Factored Forms

page.title: 7.10.0: Lesson Overview
page.contents:
In this lesson, you will continue to work with quadratic expressions and functions and learn how to show (algebraically) that two different expressions can define the same function. You will discover the connections between different forms of quadratic expressions and features of the graphs that represent the expressions. You will learn that that some numbers in the expressions are related to the \(x\)- and \(y\)-intercepts of graphs representing expressions in standard and factored form. 

When you finish this lesson, you will be able to: 

  • Explain the meaning of the intercepts on a graph of a quadratic function in terms of the situation it represents.
  • Explain how the numbers in the factored form of a quadratic expression relate to the intercepts of its graph.

Here are the activities that will help you reach those goals:

  • 7.10.1: Graphs of Linear Equations
  • 7.10.2: Quadratic Forms and Their Graphs
    • 7.10.2: Self Check 
    • 7.10.2: Additional Resources
  • 7.10.3: The X- and Y-Intercepts of Quadratic Expressions
    • 7.10.3: Self Check 
    • 7.10.3: Additional Resources
  • 7.10.4: Using the Standard Form of an Equation to Find the X- and Y-Intercepts 

After that, you’ll practice and review.

  • 7.10.5: Practice
  • 7.10.6: Lesson Summary

page.title: 7.10.1: Graphs of Linear Equations
page.contents:
Warm Up Activity

Here is a graph of the equation \(y=8-2x\).


  1. Where do you see the 8 from the equation in the graph?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

The 8 in \(y=8-2x\) means the graph intersects the \(y\)-axis at 8. The \(y\)-intercept is (0,8).


  1. Where do you see the –2 from the equation in the graph?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

The –2 is the slope of the line. You can see it, for example, by looking at \((0,8)\) and \((1,6)\). When \(x\) increases by 1, \(y\) decreases by 2.


  1. What is the value of \(x\) for the \(x\)-intercept of the graph? How does this relate to the equation?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! The \(x\)-intercept is \((4,0)\). The 4 is the solution of \(8-2x=0\).

The correct answer is 4. The \(x\)-intercept is \((4,0)\). The 4 is the solution of \(8-2x=0\).

page.title: 7.10.2: Quadratic Forms and Their Graphs
page.contents:
Activity

In an earlier lesson, we saw that an equation such as \(h(t)=10+78t-16t^2\) can model the height of an object thrown upward from a height of 10 feet with a vertical velocity of 78 feet per second.


  1. Is the expression \(-16t^2+78t+10\) written in standard form? Explain your reasoning.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

Yes. It is a sum of a squared term, a linear term, and a constant term. Written in the form \(ax^2+bx+c\), – 16 is \(a\), 78 is \(b\), and 10 is \(c\).


  1. Paola said that the equation \(g(t)=-2(8t+1)(t-5)\) also defines the same function, written in factored form. Is Paola correct? Explain your reasoning.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

Yes. Distribute the – 2 to \((8t+1)\) and you have \((-16t-2)\). Multiply this binomial by \((t-5)\). The result of \((-16t-2)(t-5)\) is \(-16t^2+78t+10\).


  1. Here is a graph representing both \(g(t)=-2(8t+1)(t-5)\) and \(h(t)=10+78t-16t^2\).


    1. What is the \(y\)-value of the \(y\)-intercept?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! The \(y\)-intercept is \((0,10)\).

The correct answer is 10. The \(y\)-intercept is \((0,10)\).

    1. What is the \(x\)-value of the \(x\)-intercept?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! The \(x\)-intercept is \((5,0)\).

The correct answer is 5. The \(x\)-intercept is \((5,0)\).


    1. What do each of these points mean in this situation?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

The \(y\)-intercept shows the height, in feet, of the object when it was thrown, and the \(x\)-intercept shows the number of seconds that passed after the object was thrown before it hit the ground.

page.title: 7.10.2: Self Check
page.contents:
The quadratic function \(y=-(x-2)(x+3)\) is graphed below.

What are all of the \(x\)-intercepts?

answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This is one \(x\)-intercept, but there are two. The answer is \(x = – 3\), \(x = 2\).
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: This is one \(x\)-intercept \((x=2)\) and 6 is the value of the \(y\)-intercept. The answer is \(x= – 3\), \(x=2\).
That’s correct! Check yourself: The graph crosses the \(x\)-axis at these two values.
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: 6 is the value of the \(y\)-intercept. The answer is \(x = – 3\), \(x = 2\).

answer.answer_text: I am not sure.

page.title: 7.10.2: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Characteristics of Quadratic Graphs

The graph of \(y=(x+1)(x-2)\) is shown below.

What are the \(x\)- and \(y\)-intercepts?

The \(x\)-intercepts are where the graph crosses the \(x\)-axis.

This happens at \((-1,10)\) and \((2,0)\).

The \(y\)-intercept is where the graph crosses the \(y\)-axis. 

This happens at \((0,2)\).

Try It: Characteristics of Quadratic Graphs


The graph of \(y=-(x-4)(x+1)\) is below.

What are the \(x\)- and \(y\)-intercepts of the graph?

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your Answer:

Here is how to find the intercepts:

For the \(x\)-intercepts: Look at where the graph crosses the \(x\)-axis.

This happens at \(x = – 1\) and \(x = 4\). So the points are \((-1,0)\) and \((4,0)\).

For the \(y\)-intercept: Look at where the graph crosses the \(y\)-axis.

This happens at \(y = 4\) so the point is \((0,4)\).

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 7.10.3: The X- and Y-Intercepts of Quadratic Expressions
page.contents:
Activity

Here are pairs of expressions in standard and factored forms. Each pair of expressions define the same quadratic function, which can be represented with the given graph.

Identify the \(x\)-intercepts and the \(y\)-intercept of each graph.

  1. Function \(f\)
    \(x^2+4x+3\)
    \((x+3)(x+1)\)


    1. Identify the \(x\)-intercepts of the graph.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

Graph of \(f\): \(x\)-intercepts: \((-3,0)\) and \((-1,0)\).


    1. Identify the \(y\)-value of the \(y\)-intercept of the graph.

Enter your answer here.

Correct! Graph of \(f\): \(y\)-intercept \((0,3)\).

The correct answer is 3. Graph of \(f\): \(y\)-intercept \((0,3)\).

  1. Function \(g\)
    \(x^2-5x+4\)
    \((x-4)(x-1)\)


    1. Identify the \(x\)-intercepts of the graph.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

Graph of \(g\): \(x\)-intercepts: \((1,0)\) and \((4,0)\).


    1. Identify the \(y\)-value of the \(y\)-intercept of the graph.

Enter your answer here.

Correct! Graph of \(g\): \(y\)-intercept \((0,4)\).

The correct answer is 4. Graph of \(g\): \(y\)-intercept \((0,4)\).


  1. Function \(h\)
    \(x^2-9\)
    \((x-3)(x+3)\)


    1. Identify the \(x\)-intercepts of the graph.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

Graph of \(h\): \(x\)-intercepts: \((3,0)\) and \((-3,0)\).


    1. Identify the \(y\)-value of the \(y\)-intercept of the graph.

Enter your answer here.

Correct!– 9, Graph of \(h\): \(y\)-intercept \((0,-9)\).

The correct answer is -9. Graph of \(h\): \(y\)-intercept \((0,-9)\).

  1. Function \(j\)
    \(x^2-5x\)
    \( x(x-5)\)


    1. Identify the \(x\)-intercepts of the graph.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

Graph of \(j\): \(x\)-intercepts: \((0,0)\) and \((5,0)\).


    1. Identify the \(y\)-value of the \(y\)-intercept of the graph.

Enter your answer here.

Correct! 0, Graph of \(j\): \(y\)-intercept \((0,0)\).

The correct answer is 0, Graph of \(j\): \(y\)-intercept \((0,0)\).


  1. Function \(k\)
    \(5x-x^2\)
    \(x(5-x)\)


    1. Identify the \(x\)-intercepts of the graph.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

Graph of \(k\): \(x\)-intercepts: \((0,0)\) and \((5,0)\).


    1. Identify the \(y\)-value of the \(y\)-intercept of the graph.

Enter your answer here.

Correct! 0, Graph of \(k\): \(y\)-intercept \((0,0)\).

The correct answer is 0, Graph of \(k\): \(y\)-intercept \((0,0)\).


  1. Function \(l\)
    \(x^2+4x+4\)
    \((x+2)(x+2)\)

    1. Identify the \(x\)-intercept of the graph.

      Answer:  

Enter your answer here.

Correct! – 2, Graph of \(l\): \(x\)-intercept \((-2,0)\).

The correct answer is – 2. Graph of \(l\): \(x\)-intercept \((-2,0)\).

    1. Identify the \(y\)-value of the \(y\)-intercept of the graph.

Enter your answer here.

Correct! Graph of \(l\): \(y\)-intercept \((0,4)\).

The correct answer is 4. Graph of \(l\): \(y\)-intercept \((0,4)\).


  1. What do you notice about the \(x\)-intercepts, the \(y\)-intercept, and the numbers in the expressions defining each function? Make a couple of observations.

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Compare your Answer:

  • The \(y\)-coordinate of the \(y\)-intercept is the constant term when the function is expressed in standard form. The \(y\)-intercept is \((0,-9)\) for the function \(h\), \(x^2-9\).
  • The \(x\)-intercepts in each graph seem to match the numbers in the factors of the expressions in factored form, but the signs seem to be the opposite. For example, when the expression is \((x+3)(x+1)\), the \(x\)-intercepts are \((-3,0)\) and \((-1,0)\).
  • When one of the factors is just a variable (rather than a sum or a difference), one of the \(x\)-intercepts is \((0,0)\). For the function \(i\), \(x(x-5)\), one of the intercepts is \((0,0)\)).
  • x(x-5) and x(5-x) have the same \(x\)-intercepts, but one graph opens upward and the other opens downward. 
  • When the two factors are the same, there is only one \(x\)-intercept. For the function \(l\), \((x+2)(x+2)\), – 2 is the \(x\)-intercept.

  1. Here is an expression that models function \(p\), another quadratic function: \((x-9)(x-1)\).

    1. Predict the \(x\)-intercepts of the graph that represents this function.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

The \(x\)-intercepts will be \((9,0)\) and \((1,0)\).


    1. Identify the \(y\)-value of the \(y\)-intercept of the graph that represents this function.

Enter your answer here.

Correct! The \(y\)-intercept will be \((0,9)\) because 9 is the constant term when the expression is put in standard form.

The correct answer is 9. The \(y\)-intercept will be \((0,9)\) because 9 is the constant term when the expression is put in standard form.

Video: Determining the X- and Y-Intercepts of Quadratic Expressions

Watch the following video to learn more about the \(x\)- and \(y\)-intercepts of quadratic expressions.




Extending Your Thinking

Find the values of \(a\), \(p\), and \(q\) that will make \(y=a(x-p)(x-q)\) be the equation represented by the graph.

  1. What is the value of \(a\)?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(a=2\)


Find the values of \(a\), \(p\), and \(q\) that will make \(y=a(x-p)(x-q)\) be the equation represented by the graph.

  1. What is the value of \(p\)?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(p=1\) or \(p=3\)


Find the values of \(a\), \(p\), and \(q\) that will make \(y=a(x-p)(x-q)\) be the equation represented by the graph.

  1. What is the value of \(q\) ?

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\(q=1\) or \(q=3\)

answer.response: Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: What value for \(x\) makes the factors zero? The \(x\)-intercepts are the opposite sign of the numbers in the parenthesis. The answer is \(x = – 2, x = 9\).
That’s correct! Check yourself: There is a -9 in \((x+9)\) so the \(x\)-intercept is 9. There is a 2 in \((x+2)\) so the \(x\)-intercept is – 2.

Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: Check your answers by substituting the values into the factors to see if they equal zero. While \(x = – 2\) is a \(x\)-intercept, \(x = – 9\) is not. The answer is \(x = – 2, x = 9\).
Incorrect. Let’s try again a different way: 9 is one of the intercepts. However, the \(x\)-intercepts are the opposite sign of the numbers in the parenthesis. The answer is \(x = – 2, x = 9\)

answer.answer_text: I am not sure.

page.title: 7.10.3: Additional Resources
page.contents:
Finding X-Intercepts Without Graphs

When a quadratic is in factored form, the \(x\)-intercepts of a quadratic equation will be:

  • the opposite sign of the constant in the factor because if \(x+a=0\) , then \(x = – a\).
  • \(x = 0\) is an option.
  • If a factor is repeated, there is only one \(x\)-intercept.

Example

Find the \(x\)-intercepts of \(y=(x-3)(x+2)\).

The \(x\)-intercepts occur when \(y = 0\). 

Set each factor to 0 and solve.

\(x-3=0\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;x+2=0\\\;\;\;\;\;x\;=\;3\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;x\;=\;–\;2\)

Notice that for the factor \((x-3)\) or \((x-3)(x+(-3)\)), the constant is – 3, so the \(x\)-intercept is \(x = +3\) or the point \((3,0)\).

For the factor \((x+2)\), the constant is \(+2\), so the \(x\)-intercept is \(x = – 2\) or the point \((-2,0)\).

Try It: Finding X-intercepts Without Graphs


Find the \(x\)-intercepts of \(y=(x-1)(x+5)\).

Write down your answer, then select the solution button to compare your work.

Here is how to find the \(x\)-intercepts:

The \(x\)-intercepts occur when \(y = 0\). 

Set each factor to 0 and solve.

\(x-1\;=0\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;x+5=0\\\;\;\;\;\;\;x\;=\;1\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;\;x\;=\;–\;5v\)

Notice that for the factor \((x-3)\) or \((x-1)(x+(-1)\)), the constant is – 1, so the \(x\)-intercept is \(x = +1\) or the point \((1,0)\).

For the factor \((x+5)\), the constant is +5, so the \(x\)-intercept is \(x= – 5\) or the point \((-5,0)\).

answer.answer_text: I’d like to retry the self check.
I’m ready for the next activity.

page.title: 7.10.4: Using the Standard Form of an Equation to Find the X- and Y-Intercepts
page.contents:
Cool Down (5 minutes)

Student Activity

The equations \(y=x^2+6x+8\) and \(y=(x+2)(x+4)\) both define the same quadratic function. 


  1. Without graphing, identify the \(x\)-intercepts of the graph. Explain how you know.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

\((-2,0)\),\((-4,0)\); The constants in the factors of an equation in factored form give a clue about where the \(x\)-intercepts are when the equation is graphed. In the equation \(y=(x+2)(x+4)\), the \(x\)-intercepts are \((-2,0)\) and \((-4,0)\).


  1. Without graphing, identify the \(y\)-value of the \(y\)-intercept of the graph. Explain your reasoning.

Enter your answer here:

Compare your answer:

8; The \(y\)-intercepts of the graph can be seen when the equation is in standard form. The \(y\)-coordinate is the number without the variable. In the equation \(y=x^2+6x+8\), it is the 8 so the \(y\)-intercept is \((0,8)\).

page.title: 7.10.5: Practice
page.contents:
Complete the following questions to practice the skills you have learned in this lesson.

  1. A quadratic function \(f\) is defined by \(f(x)=(x-7)(x+3)\).
    1. Without graphing, identify the \(x\)-intercepts of the graph of \(f\).

Correct! \((7,0)\) and \((-3,0)\). If \(x\) is 7, \((7-7)(7+3)\) gives 0 10, which is 0. If \(x\) is -3, \((-3-7)(-3+3)\) gives -10 0, which is 0.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 7.10.1–7.10.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \((7,0)\0 and \((-3,0)\). If \(x\) is 7, \((7-7)(7+3)\) gives 0 10, which is 0. If \(x\) is -3, \((-3-7)(-3+3)\) gives -10 0, which is 0. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. Use the standard form of \((x-7)(x+3)\) to identify the \(y\)-value of the \(y\)-intercept of the graph of \(f\).

Enter your answer here.

Correct! – 21 The \(y\)-intercept of the graph of the equation is \((0,-21)\).

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 7.10.1–7.10.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is – 21. The \(y\)-intercept of the graph of the equation is (0,-21). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Answer these questions for the equation \(y=x^2-5x+4\).
    1. What is the \(y\)-value of the \(y\)-intercept of this equation’s graph?

Enter your answer here.

Correct! 4 The \(y\)-intercept of the graph of the equation is (0,4).

Try again. Why don't you go back to activities 7.10.2 and 7.10.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is 4. The \(y\)-intercept of the graph of the equation is \((0,4)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

    1. An equivalent way to write this equation is \(y=(x-4)(x-1)\). What are the \(x\)-intercepts of this equation’s graph?

Correct! \((1,0)\) and \((4,0)\0. If \(x\) is 1, \((1-4)(1-1)\) gives -3 0 which is 0. If \(x\) is 4, \((4-4)(4-1)\) gives 0 3 which is 0.

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activities 7.10.2 and 7.10.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \((1,0)\) and \((4,0)\). If \(x\) is 1, \((1-4)(1-1)\) gives -3 0 which is 0. If \(x\) is 4, \((4-4)(4-1)\) gives 0 3 which is 0. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Noah said that if we graph \(y=(x-1)(x+6)\), the \(x\)-intercepts will be at \((1,0)\) and \((-6,0)\). Is Noah correct?

Correct! We can check by substituting 1 for \(x\) and -6 for \(x\) and see if they produce an output of 0. If \(x\) is 1, \((1-1)(1+6)\) gives 0 7, which is 0. If \(x\) is – 6, \((-6-1)(-6+6)\) gives -7 0, which is 0.

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 7.10.2–7.10.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is Yes. We can check by substituting 1 for \(x\) and – 6 for \(x\) and see if they produce an output of 0. If \(x\) is 1, \((1-1)(1+6)\) gives 0 7, which is 0. If \(x\) is – 6, \((-6-1)(-6+6)\) gives -7 0, which is 0. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Select two \(x\)-intercepts of this graph.

Correct! The graph crosses the \(x\)-axis at \((-1,0)\) and \((3,0)\).

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activities 7.10.2 and 7.10.3 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is – 1 and 3. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. Use the standard form of \(y=(x-2)(x-4)\) to identify the \(y\)-value of the \(y\)-intercept of the graph.

Enter your answer here.

Correct!

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activity 7.10.4. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is 8. You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

page.title: 7.10.6: Lesson Summary
page.contents:
In this lesson, you learned how to:

  • Explain the meaning of the intercepts on a graph of a quadratic function in terms of the situation it represents.
  • Explain how the numbers in the factored form of a quadratic expression relate to the intercepts of its graph.

Here are the activities that helped you reach those goals:

  • 7.10.1: Graphs of Linear Equations
    • In this activity, you located the \(x\)- and \(y\)-intercepts of linear graphs.
  • 7.10.2: Quadratic Forms and Their Graphs
    • In this activity, you looked at different forms of a quadratic and their graphs and picked out characteristics. These characteristics included \(x\)- and \(y\)-intercepts.
    • 7.10.2: Self-Check
    • 7.10.2: Additional Resources
  • 7.10.3: The \(X\)- and \(Y\)-Intercepts of Quadratic Expressions
    • In this activity, you continued looking at different forms and graphs of quadratics and identifying their intercepts. You then made observations about how the graphs and forms are related in helping identify intercepts.
    • 7.10.3: Self Check
    • 7.10.3: Additional Resources
  • 7.10.4: Using the Standard Form of an Equation to Find the \(X\)- and \(Y\)-Intercepts
    • In this activity, you used the standard form of a quadratic equation to find the \(y\)-intercept and the factored form of the same equation to find the \(x\)-intercepts.

After these activities, you completed the following practice:

  • 7.10.5: Practice

Checking In

On a scale of 1 to 5, how confident do you feel about the learning goals of this lesson?

Correct!

If you’ve answered 3 or less, be sure to reach out to your teacher before starting the next lesson.
